headings.title: The Fluidity of Rolling Stone’s “Greatest Albums of All Time” Ranking [a][b]
headings.sub: Examining what might be influencing the debate surrounding canonical music.
headings.byline: by Chris Dalla Riva and Matthew Daniels

introfirst.value: In 2003, Rolling Stone magazine released its “500 Greatest Albums of All Time,” declaring the Beatles’ “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” as #1.

introsecond.value: When the publication updated the list in 2012 to include the first decade of the new millennium, not only did the Beatles’ classic remain at #1 but the entire top 10 was unchanged.
This certitude wasn’t to last, though.

introthird.value: Rolling Stone revised the list in 2020 again, and the two decade consensus was no more.
Beyond “Let’s Get It On” jumping from #6 to #1 and “Pet Sounds” remaining locked in at #2, the entire top 10 was changed, some albums jumping scores of spots.

introfourth.value: Once again, here’s the ranking from twenty years ago. We’ve highlighted those albums that jumped into the latest top 10 from 2020.
Between 2003 and 2020, Ms. Lauryn Hill’s masterwork “The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill” moved 302 spots, from #312 to #10.

introfifth.value: But each year’s ranking isn’t just the same albums, shuffling among different positions.
Here is the complete ranking from 2020, and nearly a third of the albums were new, never appearing in previous rankings. Let’s examine those more closely.

introsixtwo.value: The “new” greatest albums of all time
Many of these albums were released over the past decade, such as Kanye West’s “My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy” (#17).
And Kendrick Lamar’s “To Pimp a Butterfly” (#19).

introsixthree.value: But other additions had been out for decades, like Kate Bush’s “Hounds of Love,” originally released in 1985.
Billie Holiday’s “Lady in Satin” made the list in 2020 despite being unranked in 2003, 45 years after its release.

popone.value: There must be other factors influencing Rolling Stone’s choices, beyond accounting for new releases.

This project uses Rolling Stone ranking, twenty years apart in time, to determine what might be influencing the “greatest of all time” discussion. We’ll also factor in who Rolling Stone chose as judges to determine the ranking, all 582 voters.
First, the music canon is shaped by what’s widely listened to.

poptwo.value: Most of the albums on Rolling Stone’s 2020 ranking were hits.
When we just look at albums ranked in the top 100, 30% charted at #1 on Billboard at the time of their release.

popthree.value: If we look at lower ranked albums, among the bottom 400, they are 3x more likely to have never charted on Billboard. In other words, if you want your album to be considered great, it helps if it is also popular.

spotifyone.value: Beyond popularity, the musical canon is also shaped by how we listen.
Earlier, we noted that on Rolling Stone’s 2003 ranking of the top 500 greatest albums, about a third would not be ranked 20 years later, in 2020.

spotifytwo.value: Here’s the 2003 ranking, highlighting the 174 that failed to rank in 2020.

spotifythree.value: We noticed a few qualities uniting these albums that seemingly fell out of favor with judges.

spotifyfour.value: 18% are compilations or greatest hits albums. These types of albums were popular in the days of physical releases, like CDs, cassettes, and vinyl. Today, anything can be thrown on a playlist; we can figure that compilations or greatest hits are lesser known to younger voters in 2020.

spotifyfive.value: 6% of the albums are not currently available on Spotify.
For example, Captain Beefheart’s “Trout Mask Replica” was #58 in 2003. 17 years later, it failed to rank.
It’s hard for an album to remain relevant if most people don’t have a means to listen to it.

spotifysix.value: Most albums absent from Spotify saw their ranking decline, including those that still made Rolling Stone’s 2020 list.

spotifyseven.value: Neil Young’s acclaimed second studio album “Everybody Knows This Is Nowhere” went from #208 to #407. Young removed his catalog from Spotify over his dissatisfaction of their support for podcaster Joe Rogan.

Funkadelic’s genre-bending 1978 album “One Nation Under a Groove” fell from #176 to #360. The album was removed from Spotify during a dispute between Funkadelic frontman George Clinton and his former label, Warner Records.

voterone.value: Next, let’s look at one of the most important factors: who’s voting.
To construct these lists, Rolling Stone polled artists, songwriters, producers, A&Rs, executives, journalists, and their staff writers. Here is who voted in 2003:

votertwo.value: Scanning these faces, something probably jumps out at you about these voters…

voterthree.value: The large, large majority of the 2003 voters were men. And while it’s difficult to pinpoint the exact racial identity of each voter, we’re confident that white men were overrepresented.

voterfour.value: For 2020 ranking, Rolling Stone, perhaps in an effort to poll beyond the music tastes of white men, expanded the voting group from 269 to 336 and doubled the representation of women voters. Here are the judges in 2020:

voterfourtwo.value: With two cohorts of voters, from 2003 and 2020, we can reflect on how different voter demographics might influence “greatest album of all time” choices.

voterfive.value: In 2003, 90% of voters were men. Not surprisingly, voters selected predominantly male performers—nearly 82% of the 500 “greatest albums of all time” were by men.

Rolling Stone published a few ballots of voters in 2003. James Hetfield’s (of Metallica) top 10 included only men. So did Billie Joe Armstrong’s (of Green Day). The most gender diverse ballot, among those published, was Britney Spears’s, with Janet Jackson, Madonna, Whitney Houston, and TLC among her top 10 albums.

votersix.value: In 2020, with more women voters, we see a curious correlation with greater gender diversity in the albums selected: albums by women or mixed-gender groups jumped from 16% to 28%.
Next, let’s consider how voters’ ages shape album selection.

voterseven.value: Here are the judges, by age group, at the time of voting.
Voters in 2003 and 2020 were spread out among similar age ranges. How might this have affected the age of the albums they selected?

votereight.value: We had a hunch that albums released during voters’ teenage years would have an outsized impact on their choices, the most formative years for music taste.
Here are judges arranged by the approximate decade of their teenage years.
In 2020, over half of the judges were teenagers in the 1990s, 2000s, and 2010s. This is a stark change from the 2003 ranking, when judges were predominantly of the Baby Boomer or Gen X generation.

voternine.value: Let’s compare judges’ ages with the release years of the 500 greatest albums of all time.
In 2003, for example, only 11 voters (4%) were teens in the 1990s. Accordingly, 74 of the 500 greatest albums of all-time (15%) were from the 1990s.

voterten.value: In 2020, the number of voters who grew up in the 1990s jumped from 11 to 90. Albums from the 1990s similarly increased from 15 to 21%.

votereleven.value: Of course, assessing the past is a messy, imperfect business. When Rolling Stone ranks the greatest albums of all time in 2030, a new cohort of Gen Zers will no doubt elevate albums from the 2000s and 2010s.
Yet, there is still some level of consistency over the decades, especially as we get further from the past.
Here we highlight the albums ranked in 2020 that also were ranked in 2003.

votertwelve.value: Of the 104 albums from the 1990s on the 2020 list, 55 (53%) were on the list in 2003.

voterthirteen.value: Of the 73 albums from the 1980s on the 2020 list, 56 (76%) were on the list in 2003.

voterfourteen.value: Of the 155 albums from the 1970s on the 2020 list, 128 (83%) were on the list in 2003.

voterfifteen.value: Of the 71 albums from the 1960s on 2020 list, 65 (92%) were on the list in 2003.

votersixteen.value: Of the 10 albums from the 1950s on the 2020 list, 8 (80%) were on the 2003 list.

conclusion.value: In short, after a certain point, when people are talking about great albums of the 1950s, they are likely talking about Miles Davis’s “Kind of Blue,” Elvis Presley’s self-titled album, and Frank Sinatra’s “In the Wee Small Hours,” among a few others.

Is it possible in 100 years that some obscure album from the 1950s will suddenly be hailed as the decade’s masterpiece? Yes. But it’s not likely. Some level of consensus does seem to appear over time, despite all of the unexpected non-musical factors that influence list construction.
